column2: a new book due in September. Edited by Nashville-based journalist
column3: songwriter
column4: producer and publicist Holly Gleason and subtitled How The Women In Country Music Changed Our Lives
column5: the University of Texas Press book will examine the relationship between female songwriters and the women of an older country music generation who inspired them. The highly personal essays will include Swift‚Äôs assessment of the 1950s pop hitmaker turned country matriarch Brenda Lee
column6: titled Rare Peer. Rosanne Cash writes about her father Johnny‚Äôs second wife June in a piece entitled Eulogy For A Mother. Up-and-coming country artist Aubrie Sellers
column7: herself from fine Nashville tradition as the daughter of Lee Ann Womack

column12: a piece about one of her heroines

column16: and Cynthia Sanz. ‚ÄúWoman Walk the Line came about because it feels like we‚Äôre not just in danger of losing the story of so many incredible artists
column18: but that deeper sense of what music can truly to mean to someone in their life
column19: ‚Äù says Gleason. ‚ÄúThe way this music and these women are written about says so much about the way music marks our lives
column20: shapes our journey or keeps us safe in rugged times. It‚Äôs women of varying ages all writing about how music touched and changed their lives ‚Äî part witness

column24: as today‚Äôs reductionist media makes it. And that‚Äôs where the marrow of these essays begins.‚Äù    Update: There is also an essay about Taylor! pictured is Brenda Lee - Taylor wrote an essay about her for this book. " False link

Sometimes it‚Äôs done preemptively to keep others from taking ownership of marks that have a strongly perceived tie to the celebrity even though the projects may never see the light of day.
